GOVERNMENT OF PUNJAB (INDIA) ECONOMIC AND STATISTICAL ORGANISATION PUBLICATION NO. 95 STATISTICAL ABSTRACT OF PUNJAB 1968 | Issued by THE ECONOMIC ADVISER TO GOVERNMENT PUNJAB FOREWORD The Statistical Abstract of the State is brought out annually by the Economic and Statistical Organisation, Punjab. The first issue of the Abstract was published in 1959. It contained data, on various socio-economic aspects of the State’s economy, collected from different sources with an aim to provide comparable and reliable statistics for planning and policy purposes. Encouraged by its increasing utility and demand every year, from the State and Central Government offices, agencies outside the country, universities and research scholars, the Organisation has been enlarging its scope and coverage by adding new tables and making improvements in the existing ones on different subjects. In the present issue, which is eleventh in the series and third after the re-organisation of the State, some tables on Area and Population, rrigation, Labour, Medical and Health, Prices and Elections have been added for the first time. In. this era. of planning, the importance of reliable statistics needs no emphasis. The present issue~will provide necessary statistical data, comparable over time and space, for watch- ing‘tne-progress of various development programmes in the state and for taking policy decisions thereon. I take this opportunity to make a request to all those who are engaged in research wd.economic analysis and legislators in particular to study the Abstract and give their valu able sugeestions for its further improvement. I am glad that Shri J.S, Sandhu, Director, Bureau of Statistics has been able to bring out this volume well in time. CHANDIGARH: KRISHAN LAL March 10, 1969. Minister for Finance, Planning and Statistics, Punjab. PREFACE This issue of the Statistical Abstract is the eleventh edition in the series and third aftey the re-organisation of the Punjab. The latest available statistics on various socio-economic activities of the State have been given in it. As in the past, the present publication will serve as a useful and informative reference book for those engaged in administrative, planning and developmental work of the Government. Research scholars and others engaged in similar activities will also find it useful for research and analysis of data on socio-economic problems, District-wise information has been given wherever possible. To make the tables lucid, relevant notes have been inserted. Coucepts and definitions used have been fully explained at the beginning of each section and some charts/maps have also been added at appropriate places. I am thankful to the various Heads of Departments and my District Statistical Officers for their whole-hearted co-operation in furnishing the data promptly as a result of which only it has been possible to bring out this publication well in time. My thanks are also due to the Controller of Printing and Stationery, Chandigarh and his staff who, despite their pre-occupation in connection with other budget documents have extended full co-operation in publishing the present issue expeditiously. Acknowledgement is also made of the useful work done by Sarvshri Jagjit Singh (Deputy Economic and Statistical Adviser), J.S. Nagi (Census Officer), P.D. Thakur (Research Officer) and their colleagues Sarvshri M. N. Rishi, M.G. Gupta, Joginder Singh, Bikramjit Singh, Kartar Singh Poonia, H.S. Randhawa, Rajinder Singh, Amar Nath, K.C. Bajaj and Roshan Lal in preparation of the Abstract and Shri H.S. Kohli for preparing charts and maps. CHANDIGARH : J. 8S. SANDHU March 10, 1969. Director, Bureau of Statistics, Punjab. SECTION I AREA AND POPULATION This Section provides data relating to area and population of the State according to 1961 Census. The data have been taken from II-A tables of 1961 Census and Primary say Abstracts from the office of Superintendent of Census Operations, Punja Payal Sub-Tehsil was a part of Patiala District formerly ; but the area of this Sub-Tehsil was transferred from Patiala to adjoining Districts of Sangrur and Ludhiana, vide Gazette Notification No. 2749-Rg-I'V-63/687, dated 12th November, 1963. Adjustments have been made in all the three districts after incorporating the data from the Primary Census Abstracts from, the office of the Superintendent Census Operations, Punjab. Table No 2.1 gives districtwise monthly rainfail figures for 1967. Table No. 2.2 shows districtwise monthly rainfall figures which are averages of five years 1963-1967. In Table No. 2.3. the data presented are atout rainfal!. The actual rainfall recorded at 08.30 hours, Indian Standard Time each day at select- ed stations throughout the State. Rainfall data given in this table reiate to 6 selected stations and have been compiled from the daily statements issued by the Regional Meteorological Centre, New Delhi. Normal rainfall figures are based on data of State rainguage stations, except for Patiala where data of observatory stations only are available. These normals are calculated from the available data collected at the respective stations up to the end of 1940, except for Patiala where the period is 1945 to 1950. Table No. 2.4 gives information § regarding temperature. These figures are also based on the daily statements issued by Regional Meteorolo- gical Centre, New Delhi and are recorded at 08.30 hours, Indian Standard Time. Highest and lowest temperatures are the highest and the lowest tem- peratures on a particular day in a month. Mean temperature is one-half of tne average maximum plus average of minimum temperatures reported during tne month, Table No. 2.5 contains data regarding sunshine. Sunshine is the condition at the earth’s surface when the sun casts a well-defined shadow. It is recorded at Amritsar by Standard Compbell Stocks recorders. lable No. 2.6 gives information in respect of Wind speed. These data are given for Ludhiana only _ Table No. 2.7 shows mean relative humidity at 6 selected stations. Relative humidity is the measure of the amount of water vapour present in the atmosphere relative to the corresponding amount for saturation. The data in respect of land revenue assessment for the State as a whole and districtwise and number of holdings are also given here. The source of information is the Director of Land Records, Punjab and the data relate to Agricultural year which starts from Ist July and ends on 30th June. Area according to village papers.—It is according to village papers and is based on returns of area prepared by village staff for revenue pur- poses in the districts, whereas area by professional survey is worked out by the Surveyor -General of Inuia. There is some difference in the two sets of figures because of different methods adopted by them. Area under Forests —This includes actually forested areas on the lands classed or administered as forest under any legal enactment dealing with forests whether State owned or private except in areas not cadastrally surveyed, Area under forests given in this section does not tally with that of the Forest Department, shown in the section on forest statistics owing to the fact that certain lands though not wooded, are taken as forest by the Forest Department while these are not treated as such by the Director of Land Records, Punjab, Land not available for cultivation.—This includes absolutely barren and unculturable land like mountains, deserts etc., which cannot be brought under plough except at exhorbitant cost, or land covered by buildings, roads and railways and water or otherwise appropriated for non- agricultural purposes. Other uncultivated land excluding fallow lands——This denotes land available for cultivation, either nct taken up for Cultivation or abandoned lateronforone reason or the other and includes culturable waste, permanent pastures and other grazing lands and lands under miscellaneous tree crops and groves. Fallow landy.—\t denotes cultivable land which after abandonment remains uncultivated over a long period called‘‘ old fallows” those kept uncultivated during the current year are cailed ‘current fallows’. Net area sown-—-\t is the net area sown under crops, the areas sown more than once during the year being counted once only. Total cropped area—-It includes total area covered with crops during the year. In case different crops are raised on the same land during the year, the same area is counted more than once. 37 LAND UTILISATION (PUNJAB STATE) 1967-68 INDEX FORESTS LAND NOT AVAILABLE FOR (eS) cuctivarion OTHER UNCULTIVATED LANDI EXCLUDING FALLOW LAND. S377] FALLOW LAND- NET AREA SOWN 38 Table No. 3.1. gives classification of area of reorganised Punjab by ate use for ten years i.e. for 1950-51, 1955-56 and from. 1960-61 to 1967-68. Table Nos. 3.2 to 3.9 present district-wise classification. Table No. 3.10 shows camparative position of various States in this regard for the year 1965-66, Table No. 3.11 presents data regarding area under and production of principal crops in the Punjab for the years 1950-51, 1955-56 and 1960-61 to 1967-68. _ Table Nos. 3. 12,3, 13 and 3. 14 show comparative position of various States in regard to the area under and production of Principal crops and yields for the year 1967-68. Table Nos. 3.15 to 3.36 present district-wise data regarding area, production and yield per hectare of principal crops of the Punjab State for the years 1950-51, 1955-56 and 1960-61 to 1967-68 and are based on revised estimates. Incidence of land revenue assessment on area in Punjab for four years—- 1963-64 to 1966-67 is shown in table No. 3. 37. The number of holdings in the Punjab with reference to year 1961 is shown in table 3.38. Figures for the affected districts have been adjusted on the basis of area. Table No. 3.39 indicates the Index Numbers of Agricultural Production in Punjab for the years 1950-51, 1955-56, 1961-62 and onwards. Tables 3.40 to 3.43 give Fertilizer’s Production in Punjab Third Five-Year Plan targets, and receipts and distribution of fertilizers in Punjab for years 1960-61 to 1967-68 and the area repartitioned in Punjab under consolidation operations for the years, 1960-61 to 1967-68, whereas the tables 3.44 and 3.45 give important indicators of development. From the year 1952-53 the yield per hectare and out-turn of wheat, gram, bajra and maize are based on the results obtaired from crop cutting experiments by random sampling method for Integrated Punjab and for rice, jowar and barley for preintegrated Punjab only. From 1956-57 all these seven crops have been covered for the whole State. Sugarcane has been covered since 1961-62 but Jowar has been excluded since 1967-68, Crop cutting experiments consist of selection of a few villages in each tehsil of a district by random sampling method, selection of a few fields in each selected village randomly and consequently selection of a plot in each selected field at random. The yield per hectare is estimated from the crop harvested on such plots. _ The data for the re-organised Punjab have been adjusted on the basis of area where the exact figures were not available and as such are provisional, PRINCIPAL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS CPUNJAB STATE) (THOUSAND METRIC TONS: \-, 64- 65- ‘66; 62° 63’ 6S’ 66% 67 ews Ear naenee OIL.
